The Related Discourses

2. Forerunners

Thus have I heard:1 One time, the Buddha stayed in the kingdom of Śrāvastī at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove.

It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks, “When ignorance is the forerunner, and it gives rise to bad and unwholesome things, then the lack of conscience and shame arises as a result. After the lack of conscience and shame arises, wrong view arises as a result. After wrong view arises, it can produce wrong intention, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong concentration.

“When understanding is the forerunner, and it gives rise to good things, then conscience and shame arise as a result. After conscience and shame arise, they can give rise to right view. After right view arises, it produces right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration, which are produced in sequence. After right concentration is produced, the noble disciple attains right liberation from desire, anger, and delusion. After the noble disciple thus attains right liberation, he can rightly know and see: ‘My births have ended; the religious practice has been established; and the task has been done.’ He himself knows that he will not be subject to a later existence.”

After he taught this discourse, the monks who heard what the Buddha had taught rejoiced and handed it down.

Endnotes

  1. This is a close parallel with the Pali SN 45.1.
Translator: Charles Patton
